page.title: 19THE GEOLOGY OF LITTONDALE
page.content: Littondale is a typical U-shaped valley. It was formed by glacial action. Some of the valleys which join it are tributory valleys showing a typical V-shape. This can be seen in the valleys of Potts, Crystal and Cowside Becks. The main rock visible in Littondale is limestone. Limestone is attacked by rain, which penetrates cracks eating away at the rock, making the cracks wider. These wider cracks are called grikes, and the limestone blocks isolated by the grikes are called clints. Together these form the limestone pavements, an example of which can be seen over Blue Scar. Erosion of the limestone over the centuries helped to form caves such as Dowkabottom and Skosca. Scars like Blue Scar, Yew Cogar and Knipe Scars are typical of limestone areas.
